instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.D7105: What is D7105? Diodes between PPDCIN_G3H charger voltage and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, when CHGR_DCIN Is low(less than charger voltage) and PPBUS_G3H is missing this is a critical point to troubleshoot.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
Hello, 

<SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> is 3.1V, F7005 is removed. Looking at schematics, I should get 20V here. Tried got known DCIN board, no change. 

Am I missing something obvious?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
If Apple original MagSafe2 charger doesn't detect any load, will not deliver more than 3V!!!
So, resolder F7005; charger needs to "see" <RESISTOR>R7012</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message: Okay, F7005 is back. Voltage jumps back and forth from 1.72V to 1.76V. Resistance on F7005 is 21.5kOhms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
Now post resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 rails.

Your charger detects leakage and get protected.
Measure onboard <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86.
This can discard a <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
We normally check power rails on diode mode, red probe to ground.
Only switch to ohm scale for low values...

Post voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> area.
Be sure <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> is not shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
Diode mode: 
3V42 - 0.281V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.415V

<DIODE>D7010</DIODE> is not shorted. Measures one way 0.745V, other way is OL.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> has 1.65V across all of it when charger connected. I feel like it could be shorted since <CAPACITOR>C7012</CAPACITOR> beeps on continuity mode with <DIODE>D7105</DIODE> on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
If short/low value on D-S, charger will detect that as leakage.
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> in this case.
I hope you checked that without charger connected...

You can use fake charger, or lab power supply to test; check if board starts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
I checked continuity without the charger connected. 
I tried injecting 20V 2A on F7005 pin 2. It pulls 0.065mA. I don't have a fake charger at the moment. Does the original charger need to be connected while voltage is injected? I saw Louis do it once if I remember it correctly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
Why 20V?
16-18V is good enough.
Then check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 rails.
Don't connect original charger, when lab power supply is used.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
I didn't fiddle more with DCPS, rather, I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR>. 

I get orange light now, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.56V. Computer doesn't start yet. Doesn't it start automatically? I guess I'm missing some more rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
I went through the list of rails and noticed <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 2.7V instead of 3.42V.

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is 36.5kOhms or 0.391V diode mode.

So to inspect that rail first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
So I have reflowed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> nice and easy since I thought it was not making a good contact. <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> looked clean. 

After reflow, I get 0 Ohms on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>... I've removed then <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, still 0 Ohms...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
There are some caps on that rail.
If still short after removed all, then bad PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
I’ve removed the caps too. Still 0 Ohms. 

Prior to reflow, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> measured around 36kOhms. I didn’t connect any power after. Could PCH reflow help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
You cannot remove a "pure" (0 ohm) short with reflow.
Crap under PCH can pull down a signal, but it will have few kohm value to ground...
Be sure you didn't make any short between some pads, with the solder iron.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message: No short between pads. Simply PCH failed for some unknown reason. Can it be replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message:
I do not recommend to waste more time on this board.
Is the worst MLB Apple made ever.
CPU power supply is known for really strange issues...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP20V_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> low, dead laptop
threads.message: Okay. Mark as solved then please.
